messageBody:
Charles:

I appreciate your thoughts on this dilemma: how to introduce QS to a wider
audience.
My assumption has always been that we would have to convince people of the
utility of using the alphabet in their personal writing, such as journals,
note-taking in school etc. Progressive schools might be able to use QS as
an initial "starter" script to get the idea of reading across to young
students. Once they have the ability to write in QS and afterwards learn
Traditional Orthography (T.O.) they would be in a position to judge how well
each of them work. I believe this is what Read meant in the QS manual, when
he said something along the lines of a new alphabet would have to stand on
its own merits to succeed.


Charles Smith wrote:

snip...

> Does anyone here actually plan on DOING anything to try to reform
> spelling? If so, how do you plan to go about it? An approach I'd
> thought of, is to introduce it slowly and gradually. For example,
> differentiate between 'th' in "this" and 'th' in "thing." Then,
> maybe make 'ng' one letter. And gradually, introduce a seperate
> letter to write each of the consonant sounds that are usually written
> with more than one (i.e. sh, ch, ng, th, dh). Note that there would
> be a small amount of time, a few months let's say, between each small
> change, allowing the populous to grow accustomed to the changes.
> Then, as soon as the consonant sounds are all introduced as one
> letter, leave that for a while, then introduce a single letter for
> each of the vowel sounds. I believe that it can actually BE DONE,
> but that it would be much easier, and much more accepted, if it were
> done slowly and gradually. What do you think?

I do not understand how you expect this to work. The problem, as I see it,
is that we have an alphabet which has major problems, but literate
English-speakers use it to communicate, despite its limitations. If a
committed group of -- say one hundred people (which is about the size of
the Shavian and Read_Alphabet community) began to use make a distinction
between voiced and unvoiced "th" sounds by the introduction of a new letter
or some alteration in the existing letters, it probably would be
comprehensible to the people who receive such communications, although it
would cause some confusion. As more changes are introduced, people who were
gradually introduced to your modifications might continue to comprehend your
writing. But inevitably, as the number of changes progresses, a
communication would be sent to someone who had not been in on the "ground
floor," so to speak, and they would not be able to comprehend your meaning
so the purpose of your writing -- to communicate -- would have been lost.
The only way to avoid this would be to try to track how many changes you had
introduced to which people, which would be impossible because you would have
to change how you write depending on who was receiving the message. Instead
of being a useful, simple tool, writing would become an intolerable burden.

Paige Gabhart.
